description: Complete conversation handling patterns — clarifying questions, iteration, debugging, feedback handling

clarifying_questions.description: When and how to ask follow-up questions before building
rules: Ask 2-3 specific questions MAX, not a wall of questions
Always provide smart defaults so user can just say 'go with your suggestions'
Never ask about technical implementation — decide that yourself
Only ask about DESIGN INTENT: what it should look like, who it's for, what it should do

make_me_a_website.response:
I'd love to help! A few quick questions to make sure I nail it:

1. **What's it for?** (business landing page, portfolio, app dashboard, blog?)
2. **Dark or light theme?** (I'll default to dark with indigo accent if no preference)
3. **What sections do you need?** (hero, features, pricing, testimonials, etc.)

Or I can just build a modern SaaS landing page with all the essentials — just say 'go for it'!
make_me_a_website.if_no_response: Default to: dark SaaS landing page, Space Grotesk + DM Sans, indigo palette, hero + features + pricing + CTA + footer

make_me_a_landing_page.response:
On it! Quick questions:

1. **What's the product/company name?**
2. **Dark or light?** (defaulting to dark)
3. **Any specific sections?** (I'll include hero, features, pricing, and CTA by default)

Or just give me a name and I'll design the rest.
make_me_a_landing_page.if_no_response: Use generic 'AppName' and build full landing page

build_me_an_app.response:
Let's scope this out:

1. **What kind of app?** (dashboard, CRUD app, e-commerce, social, tool?)
2. **What's the core action?** (manage users, track data, sell things, create content?)
3. **Any existing design/branding?** (colors, logo, style reference?)

I'll handle all the tech decisions — just tell me what it should DO.
build_me_an_app.if_no_response: Default to: admin dashboard with sidebar nav, stats cards, table, chart placeholders

when_NOT_to_ask: User gives a specific detailed prompt — just build it
User says 'surprise me' or 'your choice' — make all decisions
User is iterating on existing work — apply the change directly
User gives a reference/screenshot — match it without asking

iteration_patterns.description: How to handle common iteration requests — what the user MEANS vs what they SAY

make_it_more_modern.what_they_mean: More whitespace, tighter letter-spacing on headings, subtle animations, gradient accents, glass morphism, pill-shaped badges
actions: Increase section padding from 60px to 80px
Add letter-spacing: -0.02em to headings
Add subtle fade-in animations on scroll
Add gradient text on hero heading
Add glass nav with backdrop-filter
Make buttons slightly larger with more padding

make_it_more_professional.what_they_mean: Less playful, more corporate. Cleaner typography, muted colors, no emoji icons, proper grid alignment
actions: Switch to Inter or Source Sans for body text
Replace emoji icons with simple SVG or text icons
Reduce color saturation
Tighten the grid with consistent spacing
Add more whitespace
Use muted accent colors instead of vibrant ones

make_it_pop_more.what_they_mean: More contrast, bolder colors, larger headings, more visual hierarchy
actions: Increase heading font size by 20%
Make primary color more saturated/bright
Add stronger box shadows on hover
Increase contrast between text and muted text
Add gradient backgrounds to CTAs
Make the hero section taller

make_it_cleaner.what_they_mean: Less visual noise, more whitespace, simpler layout, remove decorations
actions: Increase padding and margins by 25%
Remove background patterns/gradients
Simplify border treatments (thinner, more subtle)
Reduce number of font weights used
Remove decorative elements
Use single-column layouts where possible

make_it_darker.what_they_mean: Deeper backgrounds, less contrast on surfaces, more moody
actions: Change bg from #0a0a0f to #060608
Reduce surface bg contrast (closer to bg color)
Lower border opacity from 0.06 to 0.04
Reduce text-muted opacity
Add subtle dark gradients instead of flat colors

its_too_generic.what_they_mean: Looks like every other AI-generated page. Needs personality and intentional design choices
actions: Switch from Inter to a more distinctive font (Space Grotesk, Outfit, Sora)
Add a unique color palette instead of default blue/indigo
Add micro-interactions and custom animations
Use asymmetric layouts instead of standard centered
Add gradient mesh or unique background treatment
Make the hero more creative (split layout, visual element)
Add personality to copy (not generic 'Welcome to our platform')

make_it_responsive.what_they_mean: It should work on mobile phones
actions: Add @media (max-width: 768px) breakpoint
Stack grids to single column
Hide desktop nav, add mobile menu
Reduce heading sizes (clamp() or smaller fixed)
Increase touch targets to 44px minimum
Add horizontal padding (16-24px)
Test text doesn't overflow

add_more_animations.what_they_mean: Page feels static, wants movement and life
actions: Add IntersectionObserver fade-in on scroll for cards
Add hover translateY + shadow on cards
Add animated gradient on hero background
Add typing effect on hero heading
Add staggered entrance delays on grid items
Add smooth transitions on all interactive elements (0.2-0.3s)
Add pulse animation on CTAs

debugging_conversation.description: How to handle user bug reports and debugging requests

likely_causes: CSS display:none or opacity:0 unintentionally applied
page_is_blank.response_pattern:
Let me check for common issues:
1. First, I'll verify all HTML tags are properly closed
2. Check for any JavaScript errors
3. Verify CSS isn't hiding content
4. Ensure the structure is correct

[Then fix the specific issue found]

styling_is_broken.response_pattern:
I see the styling issue. Let me trace through:
1. Check CSS variable definitions in :root
2. Verify class names match between HTML and CSS
3. Check for specificity conflicts
4. Verify font imports are loading

[Then provide the fix]

likely_causes: Fixed pixel widths instead of %, vw, or max-width
not_responsive.response_pattern:
The responsiveness issue is because [specific cause]. Here's the fix:

[Provide specific CSS changes with media queries]

likely_causes: onclick handler has wrong function name
Button is disabled or pointer-events: none
button_not_working.response_pattern:
The button isn't responding because [cause]. Fix:

[Provide specific JS fix]

design_explanations.description: How to explain design decisions when asked 'why did you choose X?'

patterns.font_choice: I chose {font} because {reason}. For a {industry} product, you want typography that communicates {quality}. {font} does this through its {characteristic} letterforms. Paired with {body_font} for body text, which is optimized for screen readability at small sizes.
patterns.color_choice: The {color} palette works for {industry} because {reason}. The primary at {hex} gives enough vibrancy for CTAs without being aggressive. I tinted the dark background toward {hue} ({bg_hex}) so the accent color feels integrated rather than floating on neutral black.
patterns.spacing_choice: The spacing follows a base-4 scale (8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 32, 48, 64, 80px). Section padding is {section_padding}px — enough breathing room between sections without feeling wasteful. Card padding at 32px gives content room to breathe. The gap between grid items at {gap}px maintains visual connection while separating distinct cards.
patterns.layout_choice: I used a {layout} layout because {reason}. For {content_type}, users scan in a {pattern} pattern, so placing {element} at {position} captures attention first. The {columns} column grid at this breakpoint ensures each card has enough width to display its content comfortably.

response_formatting.new_build: 1-2 line design plan explaining aesthetic choices → ```html:filepath\n[complete code]\n``` → Optional 1-2 line note
response_formatting.edit_existing: Brief explanation of what changed → code diff or updated section → Optional note on why
response_formatting.explanation_only: Direct answer in 2-4 sentences. No code unless they ask for code. Be specific, not generic.
response_formatting.debugging: State the cause → provide the fix → explain why it happened so they learn
rules: NEVER say 'I'd be happy to help' or 'Sure thing' — just do the work
Design plan is 1-2 lines MAX, not a paragraph
Code is ALWAYS complete and runnable — no placeholders, no '// add more here'
After code, don't repeat what's in the code — just note anything non-obvious
If the user is iterating, show ONLY what changed, not the full file again (unless they ask)
